metadata.h1: Reflecting on 6 Months of Leveraging Tech & Data in Theater

all_paragraphs: Written by: Yaakov Bressler, Sara Michael Jacobi, Danielle van der Eijk.

Summary: The “Leveraging Tech & Data in Theater Workshop Series” connects the theater community to technological assets and talent. Launched in December 2018 in collaboration with The Artist Co-Op and Dramatic Solutions , the workshop series aims to cover important technological topics relevant to theater professionals.
Below are the challenges we’ve faced, the solutions we’ve found, and the progress we’ve made.

There are some who feel that a large gap currently exists between available technologies and those used in the theater industry. Eventually, these individuals found each other — and formed a small group called Dramatic Solutions. Their mission:
“Provide tech solutions to the theatre industry through community.” — Dramatic Solutions
The authors choose to correspond to Dramatic Solutions as “we” and “our.”

Naturally, a group of theater enthusiasts with a flair for performance launched in-person events (guess those acting classes came in handy after all!). Aside from being positively impactful towards education¹, in-person workshops provided a community-focused platform centered around creation, participation, and action. We also really wanted to perform in an Elon Musk/Mark Zuckerberg sort of way.
We identified theater’s largest “pain points” after analyzing industry data, talking with professionals, and issuing surveys.
Here were the top 5 technological gaps we discovered:

1) Ambiguity in decision making, especially those in marketing and sales.2) Low profitability and financial sustainability.3) Low accessibility for diverse audiences.4) Extreme volatility and low profitability of Indie Theatre. 5) Deadlocked propagation of new works and talent.
We approached these obstacles with a positive attitude and a lot of research (we did mention we’re also a group of tech nerds, right?). So we rebranded “pain points” into “objectives”:

One of the most stressful elements of running a production (or a business) is not knowing what to do. What do you do when you’re not sure what to do? Yikes! Decreasing ambiguity in sales, marketing, and operations is therefore crucial for minimizing stress and allowing “the show to go on.”

It’s difficult to grow when you’re unable to financially sustain yourself or your endeavors. Theatre’s notorious unprofitability impedes the number of shows and jobs available to the industry . Establishing profitability through sustainable market practices would generate more shows, reach wider audiences, and increase financial gains for creators and showrunners.

Rapidly gentrifying neighborhoods, unfriendly zoning policies, and decaying transportation infrastructure is squeezing Indie Theatre out of its home in the East and West Villages faster than it can grow in the outer boroughs.² ³ Enabling Indie Theatre to “pop-up” in new neighborhoods and earn a profit is essential to keeping the thriving artistry of Indie Theatre pulsing.

Multitudes of talent living in NYC are frustratingly vying for a limited number of residencies, roles, or general opportunities. Increasing employment via propagation of new work would not only support our local artistic community, but also provide artists with platforms to showcase and share their work.

We were concerned that our audience would be overwhelmed by our content. Therefore, we designed our workshops around lectureship (75% of the event) before concluding our events with hands-on exercises.
We didn’t plan our events’ curriculum; we improvised and dramatically improved through feedback from participants.

Lectureship: After our first event, we realized 75% lectureship was way too much for our audience to absorb. We adjusted to 50% for the second event — then distilled it down to 25%. Moving forward, we’re going to balance lectureship with hands on per topic per skill level.

Seating: Our first two events were situated in an auditorium lecture-styled environment. Listening to our participants and working to accommodate a more “hands on” environment, we switched to a collaborative, café style set up (shown below). This new seating modification allowed participants at various skill levels to help each other. One hundred percent of our participants responded positively to this change. Moving forward, we plan on keeping the café set up.

Scheduling: Our events originally began at 6:00PM and ended at 9:00PM. The feedback helped us realize the start time was challenging for our participants’ busy schedules, so we adjusted. Now our events begin later. Moving forward, we plan on keeping the “after” schedule (in blue).

Content: The content of our workshops has been positively received, perhaps owing to our research or user self-selection. All in all, we’re excited that the most important part of our events were proven relevant. We’re now continuously sourcing for future content. If you have an idea for a workshop, get in touch with us.
Success stories from attendees in creative industries.

“After attending, I realized that I need to be strategic about how my website is laid out and that it needs to be user friendly. I redesigned my site and had a 175% increase in leads and a 30% increase in sales!
Also, using the dashboard from the workshop, I’ve been monitoring which content gets more likes and have been more strategic about how and when I post. My art is reaching the most people it ever has!

“Using some of the tools we created helps me keep in better touch with people in my network. I feel so much less stressed out and confident that I am getting work done, I’ve begun sharing this tool with people I work with and it’s inspiring that its helping them too.”
— Mike Griffiths, Marketing Director at Dixon Place

“Through the leveraging tech and data series, I feel like I’m finally using my website to its fullest potential. I know more about how people are interacting with it and I’ve made it clearer and more impactful when it comes to promoting my work.”
— Livvie Goble, Producer and Actor.

“As a young ‘artrepreneur’, there’s a million and one little things you need to worry about to make a project (or company) come to life — keeping up with how to use the latest trends in technology is almost never high on the priority list, but should be. The Leveraging Tech + Data series has proved time and time again to be an invaluable resource in helping demystify these trends and how to use them to our advantage. Thanks to their commitment in helping emerging artists, we at MT Shorts now have the tools and clear outline of actions to take in order to take our creative endeavors to the next level.”
— Greg Kamp & Sarah Ellis, Co-Founders of MT Shorts.

Yaakov: It feels great to be able to give back to the theatre while growing a nested community around the fulcrum of tech. I’m especially enthused when I see past attendees from our workshops helping others with their tech — indication that the propagation of knowledge and resources is gaining momentum.

Sara: There is something so incredibly fulfilling uniting passions — art and tech. Artists and techies have common goals —to listen, communicate and make a difference. My favorite sound will always be “Ooooohhh”, which translated means “I did it! It wasn’t as challenging as I thought, and I will do it again!”

Danielle: It’s amazing to meet individuals who are also passionate about advancing an industry which already brings me so much joy! Whether we’re discussing dashboards or musicals, I love that our community is excited to collectively tackle large problems. We’re blending science with art, storytelling, and engaging experiences.
The momentum we’ve gained from our first few months of operations indicates that the community we’re building and the resources we’re sharing are both wanted and needed.
To continue this momentum, we’re aiming our next few months on expanding our audience to include a more diverse range of skillsets. A workflow explaining our thought process is shown below:
As demonstrated, we’re introducing 2 new event types while maintaining our current Leveraging Tech & Data event. Each is briefly explained below.
A moderately structured workshop with a tight agenda but loose schedule for those interested in a specific topic.
A comprehensive course focused on the tools needed to leverage a brand across digital platforms.
An open forum to ask experts anything in a specific scope as well as an environment for collaboration.
To learn more about these events or attend, visit the Dramatic Solutions Eventbrite page.

It’s pretty amazing that just 6 months ago, the concept of a tech enabled community within theatre was nothing more than a peripherally scattered idea. Fast forward to the present and… wow! We’ve come a long way!

Reflecting upon this progress, our group is reminded of the principles that have guided us thus far — that of collective responsibility and the need for a feeling of belonging. We’re exhilarated that our efforts have granted us significant ground in both these areas. With continuation, we’ll be able to make an even greater impact.
Dramatic Solutions is a community dedicating to providing tech solutions to the theatre industry. Find out more at www.Dramatic.Solutions
